sense.name: Pull or move away or backward purposefully.
sense.commentary: Syntax Is: NP1[agent] RETREAT (PP[directional]) NOTE: May include a location retreated to. Includes metaphorical examples.
sense.examples: The enemy retreated. Retreat! The press retreated from such zeal. During the battle, Liu Bei suddenly burned his camp and retreated to the south. Congress quietly retreated to the same silk-gloved handling of the CIA and FBI in the name of national security.

sense.name: Move away, as for privacy
sense.commentary:
INCLUDES: RETREAT TO Syntax Is: NP1[agent[human]] RETREAT PP[locative]
NOTE: MUST specify the location retreated to. Compare to sense 1: this sense implies that NP1 is leaving people behind.
sense.examples: The Pope retreates to Castelgondolfo every summer. Gilbert Melendez retreated to his cell, speaking to no one. I skipped breakfast the next day and retreated to the garden with them in hand as soon as I'd dressed.

sense.name: Move back (without purpose), as from a natural process.
sense.examples: The glacier retreats a little each year. The forenoon tide had just retreated to the sea. After a three-hour intermezzo the cloud retreated.

sense.name: Make a retreat from an earlier commitment or act.
sense.examples: Conservatives have modified or retreated from their former statements of support. McCain retreated only slightly from the enthusiasm he voiced last week.

sense.name: FINANCIAL: Exhibit a quantifiable downward movement.
sense.commentary: Syntax Includes: NP1[topic] RETREAT PP[directional] NP1[topic] RETREAT PP[locative]
sense.examples: Company stock retreated a half point to 57 1/2 by closing yesterday. Stocks continue to retreat from session highs. In late afternoon trading, the euro had retreated to $1.4838.
